keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic performance in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, becoming the first pitcher in 87 years to hit three home runs in a game while starting as a pitcher.
Ohtani hit three home runs (first, fourth, and seventh innings), totaling 1,342 feet, and recorded 10 strikeouts on the mound in seven innings, showcasing his dual-threat capabilities.
The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers 5-1, securing a four-game sweep and advancing to the World Series.
Ohtani earned the NLCS MVP award for his performance, marking one of the greatest single-game postseason performances in baseball history.
This performance made him the first Dodgers player to have two multihomer postseason games, and the first since Chris Taylor in 2021.
Ohtani's performance helped shift the momentum in the postseason, especially after a previous slump (6 for 38 in postseason, 8-game homer drought).
He became the first player with two home runs in any game at 116 mph or higher since Statcast began tracking in 2015.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, Shohei Ohtani delivered one of the most extraordinary performances in baseball history by hitting three home runs (in the first, fourth, and seventh innings) and throwing a scoreless, 10-strikeout game on the mound. The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers 5-1, securing a four-game sweep and advancing to the World Series. Ohtani, a two-way star, became the first pitcher in 87 years to hit three home runs in a starting pitcher game and the first to do so in postseason play. His performance earned him the NLCS MVP award and marked the first time in franchise history that a Dodgers player achieved two multihomer postseason games. The article highlights Ohtani's resilience through a postseason slump, his rare dual-threat capabilities, and the broader context of team success, including strong pitching from the Dodgers’ rotation and team support from players like Teoscar Hernández and Mookie Betts.
title: Shohei Ohtani Delivers Historic Three-Homer, Pitching Performance in Dodgers’ NLCS Win
